2.author: chuck_portis
2.body:
A **contribution** means you are providing money to pay for something, no? As in, you deposit $100K into your investing account. That is not a taxable event.

The only taxable event is realizing a gain or receiving a dividend.

2.author: pancak3d
2.body:
No, they arent. Show me where on your tax return you're deducting your life insurance premiums to defer income taxes.

This is one of the many myths sold by the universal/whole life insurance industry. Policy salesmen are notorious for using confusing and misleading language like this, mainly because they feed their family with commission from *your* policy and *your* premiums.

2.author: pancak3d
2.body: No you are 100% wrong on that. Your money is taxed when you earn it. When you contribute $1 to a traditional 401k you get a $1 tax deduction. When you pay a $1 IUL premium you do not get any tax deduction. It is post-tax money. You pay the tax man.

2.author: pancak3d
2.body:
You have been misinformed about how these policies work, hate to be the bearer of bad news.

Do this for me: look at your tax return. On which line are you reporting these premiums and getting an income tax deduction?

The money is post tax. The *growth* inside the policy is tax deferred. Saying the money is "tax free going in" is completely incorrect. This would be like saying money is "tax free going in" to your sock drawer, which is of course untrue, because you paid income tax on that money

2.author: pancak3d
2.body:
Okay good luck creating your LLC and trying to get a tax deduction for your personal life insurance policy premiums, let us know how it goes. You'll find that [you cant](https://www.ethoslife.com/life-insurance/life-insurance-business-expense/#:~:text=In%20most%20cases%2C%20life%20insurance,coverage%20as%20an%20employee%20benefit.), unless it's an actual business with employees and a group policy, but you can certainly try!

Btw the link you shared says nothing about tax deductions

3.author: debbiewith2
3.body: Oh. Dear.  I think you have completely misunderstood the back door Roth strategy and Form 8606. The goal is not to convert just the contributions, but to empty all your traditional-type IRAs in order to move all the nondeductible basis to the Roth IRA.  Please check your 8606; you’ve likely created a tax burden and yet left behind nondeductible basis.

For 2023, I will convert the funds I deposit over to the Roth as soon as possible again, which will be $6500. The interest from those few days that the money sat in the IRA waiting to clear before I could convert to the Roth will show up at the beginning of the next month.

3.author: DDHawkeye
3.body: OK I will check it out.

3.author: DDHawkeye
3.body: So it looks like I need to convert the entire IRA, even the rolled over 401k funds into the Roth to avoid being taxed on the $6k contribution, right?

3.author: debbiewith2
3.body: Close.  It’s the conversion, not contribution, that is the taxable event.  Find out if you can roll the pre-tax assets into your current 401k.  If the conversion was in 2023, it could still be tax-free.  If it was in 2022, part of it was taxable, but at least you could get the rest of the nondeductible basis into the Roth tax-free.

6.author: BouncyEgg
6.body:
Then first, understand that rolling the Trad 401k to a Traditional IRA (or Rollover IRA, they're the same thing) will incur no tax/no penalty.

Rolling to a Roth IRA means you acknowledge paying ordinary income tax on the money.  Still no penalty, but you *will* be subject to ordinary income tax.  This stacks on top of your income and then the tax brackets applied.

So... next question... 

Are you sure you want to roll to Roth IRA (as opposed to Traditional)?  Just checking to make sure you understand before we move forward.

6.author: BouncyEgg
6.body:
Ok great!

You know the FULL 401k account value, right?  As in:

* FULL 401k value = Check written out to you + Withholdings for taxes (usually 20%)

Now, take that check and deposit it into your own bank account.

Write out a NEW check in the amount of the FULL 401k value (or click through the Fidelity screens to transfer the money).

There will be a screen that asks how you want the money coded.  You want to select the "Indirect Rollover" option.

If at ANY point you hit a snag and are unsure, just call Fidelity.  Someone will walk you through the process as you click.

6.author: financiallyfailed
6.body:
Yes to the first question. Unfortunately, I am already past this step and already deposited the check via indirect rollover option to Fidelity. 

I called Fidelity over the phone when I started this process and had them walk me through this process and they DID NOT inform me to deposit the check into my bank account and write a new check for the full amount. I am not sure what to do at this point.

6.author: BouncyEgg
6.body:
That's fine.  Then just go through *the exact same steps* and include a new check for the remaining amount.  Again, making sure it's coded as an indirect rollover.

Yes, it's that easy.

6.author: financiallyfailed
6.body: Would this count as 2 indirect rollovers in a 12-month period? The Fidelity person on the phone had mentioned something about only being allowed 1 indirect rollover every rolling 12-month period.

6.author: BouncyEgg
6.body:
It's still the same one.

Just broken up.

And anyways, 

Plan to IRA rollovers do not count in the 1x per year.  That only applies for IRA to IRA rollovers.

Yours is a 401k to IRA.

* https://www.irs.gov/retirement-plans/plan-participant-employee/rollovers-of-retirement-plan-and-ira-distributions

Scroll down to: 

* *The one-per year limit does not apply to:*

7.author: whatsit111
7.body:
This is an iffy strategy, but do you have a very trusted relative with great credit who can add you as an authorized user on a credit card? 

I did this for a relative who I love dearly but is just clueless about these things. I added her to my card but kept the actual card they sent her so she doesn't use it at all (I think I actually had it mailed to me). It's helped her credit go from I think the 500s to the low 700s in less than two years.

The catch here is that things could definitely go sideways if either of you acts badly, so only try this if you have someone you really trust. Your fiance would be the obvious choice if they have good credit, since you two should be sharing finances anyway.

8.author: sciguyCO
8.body:
Finance is a pretty broad topic, so where to start depends on what you want to focus on first.

You could try the strategy that got me through my 20's: 

Make money.  Spend money.  Screw up, get punched in the face by life, get back up, evaluate what the mistake was, and vow that'll never happen again (with varying success).  Repeat.  Occasionally stumble onto something that works well and try to continue doing that.

Or you can look through advice (like the stuff already linked), which lets you take advantage of the experience of people who had already gone through all that so you don't have to.  

**Primary rule of finances**: money going out should always be smaller (or at least equal) to money coming in.  Any shortage means you have to borrow the difference, which always costs you more in the long run.  Maybe a lot more.

That being said, not all debt is equally bad.  Having access to a big pile of money now can end up being more beneficial to your life, even with that higher cost.  Borrowing for things like an education (ideally improves your future income potential) or a house (since everyone needs someplace to live) aren't too bad.  

Plan for the future.  Spending money today is nice today, but if that leaves less for "future you", things may not turn out well.  But have a plan for those savings: some for retirement, some for "insurance" (emergency fund), some for future goals that will need money to achieve.

12.author: Apoc73
12.body:
You could also take that extra payment at the end of the year and instead tack on 1/12th  of it each month as extra.  The added money will hit your principal.  This is particularly useful at the start of the loan because the amount of interest taken out of your payment will be at its highest at the start.  This can help shave off years of a loan because you're hitting the principal.

What I tried to do with my loan is pay over at the start such that the interest payment and the left over that goes to the principal are roughly or as close to 50/50 as possible.

To answer your question about biweekly payments, it's a tactic to keep hitting the principal while the accumulated interest is at a lower point.  This recalculates your interest on the next payment to be slightly lower....but banks will hold on to your money until you give them the full amount.

16.body:
>desirable

Dental sure, but vision plans are a gimmick / a wash, and not needed if you don't need glasses, and legal is "debatable," because it depends on what you need and what the insurance actually provides.

16.author: JellyDenizen
16.body:
Obviously vision isn't needed if you don't need glasses/contacts, but if you do it will typically cover at least one exam per year and some or all of the cost of the glasses/contacts.

Legal insurance is cheap (like a couple hundred dollars per year) and pays for itself if you have even a simple legal issue every few years.

The concept of insurance doesn't really go well with the concept of "what you need." When you buy insurance you hope you don't need it, but you don't know whether you will.

16.author: FWF_scripta
16.body:

In my experience, the cost of vision insurance equals to the cost of getting an exam and glasses at Costco. Insurance allows for an annual exam, but you can only get glasses once every 2 years at locations that charge a 500% markup on glasses and the insurance doesn't cover the full cost. LensCrafters wanted $450 (only $250 with insurance) for something I got at Costco for $120. It's nuts.

As far as I know, that $200/yr ***group*** legal plan through employer doesn't cover criminal cases, it'll just refer you to a lawyer who will then bill you directly. It is very limited in what it can actually provide. The best thing I know about the plan is you might be able to get your estate planning done for free (which is awesome and would otherwise cost at least $2K around here), but not everyone needs an estate plan.

17.author: purelyforanon
17.body: This may be a silly question, I know there's several methods such as snowball. It makes the most sense to pay highest interest down first rather than paying off the lowest balance cards in terms of money saved in the end right? I appreciate your help.

17.author: beowulf90210
17.body: Yes paying down the highest interest rate loans first is called avalanche. Every dollar that remains on a 20% loan is generating twice the interest as a dollar on a 10% loan per month, so paying any dollars towards the 10% loan instead of the 20% loan (beyond the minimum of course) makes no sense to me personally. Some people advocate snowball for the psychological aspect of having fewer distinct debts to worry about, but it is mathematically a worse approach.

20.body: Um, what is her spend compared to the IRA?  If she has money needs for this and next year, a CD or laddered CDs may make sense. Depending on her comfort level - and her tax brackets - this could be out of RMDs or more than that.  It could be with half the assets or more.  Is there a large tax bill or undesirable side effects on benefits programs if this income is too high?

Would it be better to have the brother move out and boarded move in to generate income?   Where will she live if she’s forced to sell?  

A lot of moving parts.

Historically, international stocks and emerging markets stocks have [taken their turns](https://www.visualcapitalist.com/historical-returns-by-asset-class/) on the leaderboard, just not recently. 24.author: pancak3d
24.body:
If your only goal is to reduce taxes, you'd the shares which have losses.

Short term losses offset short term gains.
Long term losses offset long term gains.

24.author: bespectacledboobs
24.body: Overall my goal would be to reduce cost of selling as much as possible, and secure as much of the value of the stocks as I can. I assume that centers around tax loss reduction, but not 100% sure.

24.author: pancak3d
24.body:
You have no long term gains here, so if you're wanting to sell right now and minimize the tax impact, you'd sell for $X worth of short term gains and offset that with exactly $X of short term losses.

However ideally you'd hold longer and make them long term gains.

24.author: bespectacledboobs
24.body: What's the difference if they equal out? Isn't a higher percentage tax (short-term) of $0 the same as a lower percentage tax (long-term) on $0?

24.author: pancak3d
24.body: Not really following the question,  you have zero long term gains here to "equal out"

24.author: bespectacledboobs
24.body:
If short-term gains offset short-term losses, and the same for long-term gains and losses- what difference does it make whether the tax % is higher for short or long if the net is $0?  


Separately, if I've already sold 60 shares short-term and have an overall short-term loss of -$3840, is my best next move to sell $3840 worth of short-term gains, or wait for more lots to become long term in the next few weeks?

24.author: pancak3d
24.body:
>If short-term gains offset short-term losses, and the same for long-term gains and losses- what difference does it make whether the tax % is higher for short or long if the net is $0? 

It doesnt? I just dont follow because you don't have any long term gains and you have limited short term losses. My point about holding was that if you sold off too much of these short term gains right now, you wouldn't have enough short term losses to offset the tax burden.

>I've already sold 60 shares short-term and have an overall short-term loss of -$3840, is my best next move to sell $3840 worth of short-term gains

Yes

24.author: bespectacledboobs
24.body:
**Hypothetical**: Let's say I have $3000 in short-term losses and $3000 in short term gains. If I sell both, I realize a $0 profit and so tax rate (short term capital gains) \* $0 = $0  
Now let's say I do the same with long term losses and gains in a month. I sell both, I realize a $0 profit and so tax rate (long term capital gains) \* $0 = $0

If I'm offsetting, what does it matter whether they're long term or short term?  


**Actual**: I've actually sold for a short-term loss of $4078 and a short-term gain of $236.18. At this point, should I be selling $2763.82 ($3000 - 236.18) of short-term gains to offset the 3k in loss I already sold?

24.author: pancak3d
24.body:
It doesn't

My point about holding was that if you sold off too much of these short term gains right now, you wouldn't have enough short term losses to offset the tax burden.

Hypothetical: you sell off $8000 of short term gains. You cannot offset them all because you don't have enough short term losses. You will pay short term cap gains tax that could have been avoided if you held longer

24.author: bespectacledboobs
24.body:
Thanks very much for your help!  


If I understand correctly then, the best lot to sell in order to create a short-term gain to offset the already sold short-term losses would be those with the highest gain and lowest cost basis?

30.author: sephiroth3650
30.body: The law says "If, within 35 calendar days after mailing of the claim **payment**".  A settlement offer and a claim payment are not the same thing.

30.author: aamfs94
30.body: Ok I appreciate your input, thank you

30.author: aamfs94
30.body: I’m sorry, but I can tell you that the company will not be mailing me a check unless I agree to accept it. To the extent that your reading of that purely procedural provision is correct, I would say it’s superfluous. Not a single insurance company will mail their insured a final check unless the insured has completely agreed to accept the final amount and waive their right to challenge it.

30.author: sephiroth3650
30.body:
All of that doesn't change the fact that sending you a settlement offer is NOT the same as sending you a claim payment.  An offer to pay you something isn't the same as actually being paid.

Again....you may have an argument to a larger settlement if you can justify that the actual cash value of your car is more than what they've offered.  But you're applying the above law to a situation that you aren't in yet.

Edit to add:

>unless the insured has completely agreed to accept the final amount and waive their right to challenge it.

That's the reason for the law.  So that the insured doesn't get pressured to accept a low settlement offer on the promise that they can buy a comparable vehicle for a given price, only to find out the numbers are bogus and anything actually comparable costs $5k more.  The law is the state stepping in and saying that if an insurance company does this to you, you have 35 days to come back at them and make them pay up the difference in what they previously paid you, and what you actually need to spend to buy a comparable vehicle.

30.author: aamfs94
30.body: The right of recourse is used to challenge a low-ball offer. But you're saying I'll never ACTUALLY be able to challenge a low-ball offer, because the company will never mail me a check unless I'm already willing to accept it. Does that make any sense to you?

30.author: sephiroth3650
30.body:
Who ever said you didn't have the right to challenge a low ball offer?  Go back and read my responses.....I NEVER said that.  What I'm saying is you're applying that law incorrectly to try to use THAT as your basis for challenging the settlement.  That law is for the case I listed above....where they push you to accept a shitty offer and you find out afterwards you cannot actually buy a comparable car for that price.

You can absolutely continue to negotiate with the insurance company if you can justify the argument that their offer is low.  Your path on that is making a counter offer with your proof, and then generally going up the chain to the state's insurance regulator to seek resolution/arbitration.  That, or start a lawsuit.

30.author: aamfs94
30.body:
I'm sorry. Under law, the right of recourse I cited is the only way to formally challenge a low-ball offer. Of course I can "negotiate" with them. But those negotiations are meaningless. The company will always low-ball me. The law I cited is the only provision requiring them to put up or shut up.

You have basically said this provision is unusable. So, in effect, you are saying I have no meaningful or effective way of challenging their offer.

I respectfully disagree with your assessment. I do believe this provision is usable, as your reading would render it unusable in every single instance.

30.author: sephiroth3650
30.body:
OK.  You've been given advice on the matter, and you're unwilling to listen to any of it.  You're misunderstanding how the process works, and are hell-bent on mis-applying another law to this situation.  So I'm going to tap out.  I wish you the best of luck on this situation, and I invite you to contact your insurance carrier and cite the above law as a basis to increase the settlement offer.

Fun fact : I'm a former insurance agent who was licensed in all 50 states in the areas of property, casualty, accident, life, and health.  Which includes auto insurance.  I haven't practiced in a number of years b/c I switched career paths, but I may have a rough idea on how this works.  In any case, as I said, I hope things work out for you.

30.author: aamfs94
30.body:
Thanks for your advice. And I'm not disregarding it, I'm simply trying to understand it. As you've interpreted the law (i.e. the "right of recourse"), no human being would ever actually be able to take advantage of it, for the reasons I described. I simply do not believe that is what the law means, otherwise it serves no purpose. You haven't provided an effective counter to this explanation, which is why I'm doubting your interpretation. 

If you can actually come up with a plausible scenario by which an actual human being could take advantage of the "right of recourse" as you're interpreting it, I'm all ears.

30.author: sephiroth3650
30.body:
>That's the reason for the law. So that the insured doesn't get pressured to accept a low settlement offer on the promise that they can buy a comparable vehicle for a given price, only to find out the numbers are bogus and anything actually comparable costs $5k more. The law is the state stepping in and saying that if an insurance company does this to you, you have 35 days to come back at them and make them pay up the difference in what they previously paid you, and what you actually need to spend to buy a comparable vehicle.

So for the 2nd or 3rd time.....the law is there so that if you accept a settlement based on bad faith numbers given by insurance for comparable cars in your area, and then find out after being paid that you cannot actually find any comparable cars like they listed, that you can go back at them to force them to pay the difference b/w what was already paid and what you need to actually buy a comparable.

30.author: aamfs94
30.body: Ok this makes sense, thank you.

39.author: sciguyCO
39.body:
For purposes of earning eventual retirement benefits, Social security only looks at income from working a job, mainly because that's the only income where you owe/pay social security taxes.  This can be as an employee (which gets her a W-2 with SS tax withheld) or being "self employed" (since she'd then pay self-employment taxes which includes social security).  Whether that income goes into an individual bank account, joint bank account, or cash under her mattress does not matter.  Any past work she may have done will be credited to her, but nothing for years where she doesn't have a job.

Capital gains from investment do not trigger social security taxes, so generate no credits.  The account used for investment being individual vs. joint doesn't change that.

As another factor, *you* would be earning credits for your own benefits from your job.  Social security does pay spousal benefits, based on the credits and past income of the working spouse.  So even if she had nothing of her own, she'd still get something from that, in addition to your own SS checks.

Can the debt collection agency create a collection account for this debt that will show on my credit? If so, what data would the collection account even show?

44.author: Dfndr612
44.body:
They can make an entry on your credit report only if they are a member (subscriber) of a credit bureau. 

Some collections agencies are members and many are not. 

Take a look at the collection agency’s web site.  Usually they will have a reference about credit bureau membership. 

You can dispute any incorrect information they report via the credit bureau’s online dispute process. If the debt isn’t confirmed in 30 days it will be removed.

50.author: Bummedoutntired
50.body:
Say I won 10k but needed groceries and used 300$ out of the 10k leaving me with 9.7k will I still have to pay of that 10k in full even if I use some of my wins earnings? Sorry if I’m not making sense.

For example if i win 8k should I not touch my money and just save it all to pay the taxes? What happens if I spend all 8k and I don’t have the money to pay the taxes?

50.author: BouncyEgg
50.body:
> will I still have to pay of that 10k in full even if I use some of my wins earnings? 

Yes.

The win is when the taxable event occurs.  The fact that you used the money on groceries (or whatever) doesn't matter.

> What happens if I spend all 8k and I don’t have the money to pay the taxes?

You can request a payment plan with the IRS on the IRS website.

50.author: Bummedoutntired
50.body: So should I not spends any of my earnings? Is their a specific window that I have to pay this all and then I get to use the rest of my money untouched?

50.author: BouncyEgg
50.body:
For a quick and dirty estimate, you can use an income tax calculator like this:

* https://smartasset.com/taxes/income-taxes

Start with entering your income from work.

Write down all the tax owed.

Then enter  your income from work *plus* the gambling winnings.

Write down the new total tax owed.

The difference between this number and the previous number you wrote down is a rough estimate of the additional tax owed.  This calculator is for 2022, but it'll be good enough for 2023.

50.author: Bummedoutntired
50.body: Did the calculator, I don’t have a job and any money I get is from family member at-lest up to this point in 2023, I put in my total earnings in total from my gambling it can out to around  950$ in take home pay and 80$ in fica, would I just now pay back the 80$ doesn’t sound bad at all and can I pay for it with my take home pay from my earnings?

50.author: BouncyEgg
50.body:
> 80$ in fica,

So FICA doesn't actually apply to gambling winnings as it is considered *unearned income*.

So you don't have to pay the $80.

If you have no income, you may not actually even have a filing requirement.

* https://www.irs.gov/help/ita/do-i-need-to-file-a-tax-return

55.author: dwntwnleroybrwn
55.body:
Target Date Funds are set it and forget it funds that adjust their asset allocation (stock:bond ratio). This is important as you get older to prevent massive losses during a downturn like now. Fidelity, Schwab, and Vanguard all have low cost TDFs available. 

ERs are Expense Ratios, so basically you'll pay a "maintenance fee of 1.4% for every $1,000 in the account. That adds up quickly. NWM is likely also charging you fees when you buy/sell in the account as well. The 3 above don't do that either for their TDFs. 

Long story short they're robbing you blind and the big 3 above will help you transfer and set you up with low costs accounts without even charging you a consultation fee.

56.author: FirstSonOfGwyn
56.body:
I don't think you've given enough info to fully understand. 

What type of deposit did you make (its atypical to make a deposit in most situations)?  

you must have signed something to authorize the deposit (I've done this on like a hot used car that I didn't want sold underneath me, but I needed time to actually get to the car), what is the language there; when is it refundable vs not?

what did the rate change from -->to?  

Have you asked them if they'd play ball at the lower rate?  Have you shopped the loan, perhaps you can even beat this new lower rate?

56.author: FirstSonOfGwyn
56.body:
2.9 isn't a bad rate to begin with... see if they'll honor the 0.9%.  

Still can't tell you if the deposit is refundable or not w/o seeing what you signed.  

Its unlikely an outside lender can beat 2.9, and certainly won't beat 0.9% (that isn't a 'real' rate, its the dealer's internal lender offering a below market rate to move cars) 

If you want the car and/or don't want to lose the $500 (if its not refundable) and they won't go to the 0.9%, then, kind of is what it is, again, 2.9% isn't a bad rate.

56.author: creative-warrior159
56.body: Is there a way I can approach asking for it to increase my chances of getting it lowered?

56.author: creative-warrior159
56.body: Also, what did you mean it’s not a real rate

56.author: FirstSonOfGwyn
56.body:
you can 1- figure out if the $500 is refundable if you walk, 2- be actually willing to walk, 3- otherwise triple check everything you've signed, what the 0.9% program is etc. and see if you qualify, maybe its based on the day you get the title signed over or something, no way for me to know from here.  

I've had dealers play ball when they don't technically have to, i've had dealers being insufferable assholes when they didn't need to, I've helped out dealers when I didn't need to.  

If you have leverage, use it (like the ability to walk and get your refund back on a car they already are into at least on transpo costs).  always be genuine and polite, but firm.  good luck!

56.author: FirstSonOfGwyn
56.body:
so a bank/lender that isn't associated with the dealer, they need to actually make money lending money.  That is their business. 

the lender attached to a dealer is called a 'captive lender' and they differ from a traditional lender because they literally are a business unit within the dealership.  

What that means in practice is that a captive lender can OK deals that are 'bad deals' from a cost of capital angle (like loaning at 0.9%) because the net deal is positive for the dealership (because they make money on the car sale, make quota, yadda yadda) 

or said otherwise, the dealership likely isn't actually doing these loans at 0.9%, they are using the 0.9% as a loss leader to move cars... somewhere along the way they are buying that money at \~3% (or otherwise some rate above 0.9%) but are placing/making up that cost elsewhere on the deal that they put in front of you (the cost of the car, any extras they sell you, those are the money makers) 

I hope that makes sense.  its a bit of a visual trick on the buyer, but its not a scam or anything, its very common.

With treasuries, there are a variety of maturities. The 1YR T-Bill is exactly what it sounds like - a 1 year duration note. You give the government your money for 1 year, they return it (+interest) after a year. (slight over simplification)

There is a 2yr, 5yr, 7yr, 10yr, 15yr, 30yr etc etc

you can also sell at any time (although then you have market price risk and it is no longer a true risk free trade)

60.author: BouncyEgg
60.body:
> the free options provided by the IRS actually give LESS back in my taxes by almost $100+

Then it's something you're entering into the software that is different.

*All* tax software, assuming accurately entered data, will produce the exact same results.  Everything is following the same rules in filling out the same forms.

Even going to a tax professional will yield the exact same results.

It's typically not a software problem when you get different results.  It's almost always a user entry issue.

All I know is after 4 hours I threw in the towel and paid freetaxusa to do it for me.  Taxes are bullshit.

60.author: gubaguy
60.body:
I cleared all the info and started over from scratch and got 3 different results on 3 different sites.

Going with freetaxusa, turbotax is dead to me, and the other site still claims I owe money when two of the other three (and turbotax) all say I am owed money.  Its also goong on 2 am and I am exhausted.  Literally spent the last 4 hours doing taxes.  At this point I have paid for my taxes to be done, and if it's wrong then it's the fault of the company for doing ot wrong.  I entered in my info correctly, and even imported some directly from a pdf given to me by the IRS.  So if THATS wrong then it's really not my fault.

60.author: BouncyEgg
60.body:
> if it's wrong then it's the fault of the company for doing ot wrong

> So if THATS wrong then it's really not my fault.

While I can understand and may even empathize with your emotional reactions here, when you are in a calmer state of mind, perhaps consider that the IRS doesn't care who *you* choose to assign fault to.

Submitting an inaccurate/incorrect tax return is viewed as *your* fault from the standpoint of the IRS.

The IRS is very understanding and forgiving, but it is *you* who is ultimately responsible for certifying that the information provided to the IRS is accurate and true.

Why you are getting 3 different results on 3 different sites, I don't know.

But what I can tell you is that you should absolutely take the time to generate the 1040 (and associated forms/schedules) from each and go through them *line by line*.  Then figure out which one is the accurate one.  If you want, you can then go back and figure out what errors were made in data entry.

Sometimes, it's difficult to think logically when we are tired.  Emotions can cloud judgement.  Consider working on this project at another time when you have your patience meter refilled.

65.author: tmoney144
65.body:
I was responding to a comment that said "they don't care how long it takes" and "re-payment plans can be a lifetime," which is not true, because tax debt eventually expires and the IRS absolutely cares about you paying it before that date. As you can see, by the text you quoted and highlighted, the IRS will levy you if they think they can be paid before the CSED expires.  
  
YOU then said "the debt doesn't 'expire' if it's being serviced though payments" which is just 100% false.  
  
I was not suggesting OP try to run out the clock, that's a terrible idea. I'm just trying to correct the misinformation that is rampant in this sub from people who don't know what they're talking about, giving advice on what they "feel" is correct or how it "should" work instead of how it actually works.

From you posting, I suppose you score a point for 'absolutism' but accomplish little else.

Yay!  You're *technically* correct, but also wrong.  I suppose in one sense though it simply points out that the IRS wants their money.  You can make a payment plan, and if it's within the timeframe they will play softball.

If you're up against the wall on the 10 year limit, they'll just bend you over and take what they are owed, with a little less nuance and care.

Also, never ever said "they don't care how long it takes".  Go back and read again, none of my previous comments are edited.  Perhaps you're in such a hurry to make such a non-point you were misreading?  It certainly didn't come from my mouth.  I specifically noted the 10 year timeframe.  

Ease up, Francis.

66.author: lucky_ducker
66.body:
If their *only* income is Social Security, they are "judgment proof" and should simply stop paying it.

The only debts that can garnish SS benefits are amounts due to Federal agencies (including the IRS), child support, alimony, or court ordered victim's restitution. Even then only 15% of SS benefits can go to garnishment.

Is mom getting SSDI? If so she should be on Medicare, which starts two years after disability commences.

76.author: FWF_scripta
76.body:
These apps, especially the free ones, collect your data and can do whatever they want with it, you have zero control over that. Sometimes even they don't know who they share your info with, because they use ready-made third-party software components to build their app.

I use spreadsheets to keep track of everything -- all accounts, transactions, due dates, balances, etc. It's more manual work (though not much more, since you manually categorize all your transactions anyway) in exchange for not being concerned about security and privacy of my personal and financial information.

Every PPO I've seen covers doctors visits with a copay in addition to the free stuff mandated by the ACCA (which you linked to).  Basically a PPO provides these to help encourage people to go to the doctor to avoid small stuff turning into big items,

A HDHP only covers the list you linked to and possibly a few other items before you hit your deductible.

It seems like OP's plan refused to pay some things which I'd expect a PPO to cover, but OP says this isn't a HDHP.

I know these might be legal, but it would be a really crap plan to set it up so it no only doesn't have coverage for routine office visits but it also isn't HSA compatible.

I'm guessing that the either the service they didn't pay got coded in a way which doesn't look like an office visit (so they think the deductible applies), or the OP has a HSA-compatible HDHP and doesn't know it since it's buried in the paperwork, or the insurance company has some problem with the service in it's entirety and refused to pay it at all (or count it against the deductible).

81.author: avalpert
81.body:
Why would you compare current rates with past performance? What is the current yield of BND... Why are you comparing a product that has a varying maturity with one that holds it constant?

At any given moment for any given duration bonds and CDs will be pretty close and one may be better than the other - but you need to understand the products you are considering to compare them properly.

81.author: UnderstandingFalse43
81.body: Good point.  I understand exactly what you're saying.  Thanks for the input.

81.author: UnderstandingFalse43
81.body:
I understand that.....but the current rates are the exact reason why I ask.

If I know I can get 4.75%+ for the next two years locked...why not take it?

Already have enough risk exposure with stocks.  BND might go down -13% to -15% in a year, like last year, while 4.75% is 4.75%.  If CD's were giving 0.5% right now it wouldn't be a question, but they aren't....so why not locked in now and then move to bonds as CD rates lower?  That's all I'm asking.  Is it crazy to take the 4.75% and then move towards bonds after the CD matures if rates have dropped?

81.author: avalpert
81.body:
Because in two years when you need to reinvest maybe rates will be much lower and you would have been better off locking in a lower rate for a longer term today. Because other investments might perform better than that over the next two years. Because rates may go up tomorrow and the value of that bond you locked in will decrease because of your lost opportunity costs.

Again, you aren't making the right comparisons - you can get two year bonds too. So this isn't about CD vs Bond, this is about a two year declining duration fixed income vs a 6.5 year fixed duration fixed income product. What duration is right for your goals with the investment - what are your goals for the investment?

82.author: Bangkok_Dangeresque
82.body:
Got it. Then the "what you may owe" is likely the final word on the matter.

Unless the hospital submitted a claim for the wrong thing, or is billing you for more than what the insurer says they're supposed to, that's the final price for the service.

The way it usually works is;

1. Sticker price for the services you received from the Hospital = $4k.

2. The hospital (if in-network) and the insurer have a deal that says for their covered members, it's actually discounted to $2k

3. You and your insurance together pay the $2k. If you have a deductible and haven't met it yet, you pay for all of it yourself until you reach the deductible. If you've already met your deductible this year, then your insurer will pay a chunk, usually something like 80% or 90% of the $2k. Your insurer does that math for you, and tells you (in the document you found) how much you personally owe out of pocket.

83.author: Werewolfdad
83.body:
>	So the only Roth I have access to is my 401k and IRA.

Sure. *Right now*.  Gotta look at it across an entire career though.

83.author: Nagisan
83.body:
> Whether or not this makes sense depends on what you expect your tax liability will be in the future. If you're retired and expect to have a source of income that provides 400k outside of your 401k or ira retirement accounts, then it would make sense if you're making 70k now.  

I *do* plan on having about $40k of a pension (which is taxable), once SS hits that's another $35k or so (which will also add taxable income).  

So before I even get to retirement accounts I'll have $40k or more of taxable income soaking up the standard deduction and low tax brackets.

83.author: Nagisan
83.body:
And if I'm in a higher tax bracket in that future (where I have more access to Roth), then I'm paying higher taxes than if I did less Traditional and more Roth *now*.  

-------------------------------------

I'm legitimately trying to make the math *not* work, because I kinda want to be wrong on this...I'm just failing to make the numbers fail.  

Lets say my AGI is $50k or $51k (depending on Traditional or Roth), and lets say the higher AGI causes an additional $200 in taxes. Lastly, lets say I have $1000 cash I can afford to put in a taxable brokerage with the lower AGI, and after doing all this my take-home is $25k (lower AGI).  

If I lower my Traditional by $1000, my taxes go up $200 which means net income goes up by $800 (because $1k less is going into my 401k). This gives me $1800 cash (the $1000 cash I had before + the $800 after-tax from lowering my traditional).  

So the comparison is:  

1) $1000 cash into a brokerage with $25k net pay afterwards.  
-vs-  
2) $1000 into Roth with $25.8k net pay afterwards (the $800 remaining after lowering my Traditional).  

I feel like I'm missing something, maybe it's just too late but it seems to favor swapping out Traditional for Roth in the situation where a taxable brokerage is generally recommended.

83.author: Werewolfdad
83.body:
>	And if I’m in a higher tax bracket in that future (where I have more access to Roth), then I’m paying higher taxes than if I did less Traditional and more Roth now.

Doesn’t matter if you’re forced into Roth because you’ve always maxed out traditional.  Only matters if you have a choice between the two.  

I’ll check your math/logic in the morning.

83.author: Nagisan
83.body:
I found [an article](https://thefinancebuff.com/roth-401k-for-people-who-contribute-max.html) that confirms my thoughts - essentially what happens is the Roth dollars can, depending on your situation, be *more* valuable than Traditional + Taxable. In that situation, you gain more by switching some Traditional to Roth instead of keeping it all in Traditional and using a Taxable account for the excess. It only applies if you're maxing your 401k.  

Additionally, for myself personally, I'll most likely have a decent pension (which adds taxable dollars in the lower brackets), so I'll have less space to convert Traditional to Roth later than others might.

83.author: Werewolfdad
83.body:
That's a good article.  I think there's an argument for taxable though providing flexibility since you can save the tax savings then stuff those funds into one of the additional Roth options available later in life (such as getting access to MBDR or catch up contributions).  

>I'll most likely have a decent pension

Knowing this now, then yes, I'd agree that roth likely provides you a bit more value than someone without a pension.  That's actually one of the caveats I carve out

86.author: ahj3939
86.body:
It doesn't always get sold. Be glad they didn't sell it to collections and you didn't have to deal with that.

What I recommend is you lay low for the next few months and hope they don't get around to suing you.

Creditors and debt collectors can and do monitor your credit reports.

Say you're a bank with 10,000 accounts averaging $2500 each that are past due. That's $25 million in reciables you are sitting on.

But you aren't going call each person 10 times, send each one 10 letters, and sue every last one. That costs money.

If you pulled their credit reports and found 40% of those people took out a mortgage, bought a car, etc you might go after those first because you can garnish your wages and take 25% of their check and you don't care if they can't pay their car or mortgage, you just want your money back.

Therefore laying low with any sort of large purchase financed or credit rebuilding activity for the next 5 months would be one of the most prudent moves you can make.

Also if you happen to move in the next few months, especially far away, avoid anything that would get your new address placed on your credit reports because that's one of the first places they will search if they're trying to find you.

Heck if it's been a few years since you went and pulled a credit report I would even avoid that, especially if you never pulled a report with your current address.

86.author: Diyer2008
86.body:
So I agree with laying low but a few things you mention aren't correct. Its a violation of the FDCPA for a creditor to check or monitor your credit for the purposes of collecting debt. If the account is closed as mine are, they have no legitimate or legal purpose to check my credit without permission. So if they did this (I checked and they haven't) I'd sue them.

Also, wage garnishments in my state (PA) as only permissible for tax purposes and in our state joint assets (all mine are) are not able to be liquidated and a lien put on it for a judgement again one person.

I'm not moving anytime soon. I own my house and have no plans on moving (ever! lol) or taking out any more debt. I'm on a path to be completely debt free in the next 5 years and my credit will be restored in 3 (after all of this falls off my report).

I'll just wait out these next 5 months and see what happened. Both creditors are known for sell debt not pursing it through the legal system themselves so I'm hopeful it won't get to that point any time soon.

I was just wondering if this was normal as I've never seen it before.

86.author: ahj3939
86.body:
It's in the FCRA: https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/15/1681b

> consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances ... To a person which it has reason to believe— intends to use the information in connection with review or collection of an account of, the consumer

Also go to equifax, experian, or transunion they have products used for collections such as the Equifax Recovery Report that "Better determine a consumer's ability to pay with information on open credit, the presence of mortgage trades and other credit data reflective of liquidity." 

https://www.equifax.com/business/product/recovery-report/

And then I can pull out the data points

[I see several Collection Agencies soft pulls on my credit reports](https://ficoforums.myfico.com/t5/Rebuilding-Your-Credit/Collection-Agency-Soft-Pulls/td-p/5305828)


[I've been noticing that Portfolio Recovery Associates is listed under companies that have soft pulled my credit report](https://ficoforums.myfico.com/t5/Rebuilding-Your-Credit/Portfolio-Recovery-Associates-keeps-soft-pulling-my-credit/td-p/6032291)


[I pulled my annual credit report a few days ago and noticed that a collection agency soft pulled my Experian report towards the end of November](https://ficoforums.myfico.com/t5/Rebuilding-Your-Credit/Collection-Agency-soft-pulled-credit-report-should-I-do-anything/td-p/5456970)

86.author: Diyer2008
86.body: Got it. I just looked at the soft inquires and found a bunch from the creditor that just sued me and then didn't bothered to show up to court which resulted in a decision in my favors. Luckily, these two creditors haven't pulled my reports so here to hope June gets here fast!

88.author: ahj3939
88.body:
Does the letter say who the current creditor is?

If the current creditor is the school it means they own the debt.

You can always go back and dispute any inaccurate info. In the worst case what will happen is you end up with $0 balance collection accoutn which is the default you should expect one one does pop up on credit report.

And if it's not on the credit report what you do is pay school ASAP.

Then you assert your legal rights and write back to the debt collector (within 30 days) disputing the debt. Here is a quick dispute letter I love to use in these cases that sates the important facts and nothing else:

> Dear debt collector:
> 
> I recently got your notice about account # 123 from ZYX School.
> 
> I am disputing this invalid debt. On 1/31/2023 I spoke with Peggy at XYZ School accounting department who confirmed the balance on account #123 is $0.00 with no balance owed.

Don't admit the debt is valid or that you paid.

Okay thank you. It says the colleges name on it. I'll contact the school tomorrow, check to see if the debt is correct, pay it off, and then ask for an account balance (showing $0) to be emailed so I can provide it to ConServe.

93.author: Spiritual_Jaguar4685
93.body:
Ok, I didn't want to ask your salary, but since you offered it I can update my advice.

In theory, your debt is "bad" debt, meaning your interest is more than you'll likely get on the market. 

The 401(k) is free money, so absolutely get that match first. 

Then get rid of your credit card debt. 

After that, shift to the Roth IRA. In theory you are in a "low" tax bracket at the moment, our current income taxes rates are historically low AND you're not a super high earner. That means the "smart" bet is paying your income taxes *now* rather than in retirement. Once you start to earn around $73k the law starts to reduce how much you're allowed to put into a Roth IRA, at \~$82k you can't anymore. 

So here's the plan for you - get your match, pay off your debt, then start pumping up your Roth IRA. You're allowed to put in a maximum of $6,500 into your Roth IRA right now, I assume you won't be hitting that level but if you can, *do it*. 

If you're a super-saver and you can save beyond the $6,500 *or* your get more compensation start going past the $73k limit, then start moving your contributions back to the 401(k).

94.author: ahj3939
94.body:
Proper answer is key because you usually have 20 days to respond.

After that if *proper* answer wasn't filed with court and copy sent to the other attorney they basically go back to court and judge gives them a paper that lets them garnish your wages and bank account (if state law permits).

Basically court is a big bureaucracy.

Chase goes to court and sues you. You can see in the lawsuit there are a bunch of numbered points such as 1. your name is bob 2. you live in collin county texas 3. you opened account with chase bank 4. your balance outstanding was 4,322.32 on 2/15/2022, etc

Basically the way that court works is anything they say is true unless you file something to oppose it and then they have to provide proof such as a full accounting of charges, interest, and payments to add up to that amount.

Therefore a proper answer is going to look like 1. agree my name is bob smith 2. agree I live in Collin County Texas and everything else about the account, the balance, the interest rate, etc is going to be " deny" 

Start the negotiation with "I have $1000 in the bank, need $500 for rent on the 1st... are you willing to settle this for $500 today" and go from there.

94.author: Itsjustaylv
94.body: What if they have attached copies of my statements? Do I still deny?

94.author: ahj3939
94.body:
Yes. You would never file an answer accepting everything.

If you accept everything it's actually worse than ignoring. If you accept everything they just go back to the judge and because you accepted everything there is no legal issue at hand and they win automatically. They will get summary judgement.

This is worse than ignoring it because in many states you can often go back to court say 2 months later and plead "excusable neglect"  to get the default judgement overturned.

If you admit to everything you have much less window to do anything because you got the notice, went to court, and said everything they claim you owe is 100% correct with no dispute.

You're being sued by original creditor and they have all the records. All this does is buy you some time. In fact I should have mentioned you should not be in a rush to file answer. Know your deadline and file answer say 5 days before it's due. Don't file answer 15 days early!

What I recommend you do is go in creditboards.com and register an account and then look for the Help! I've been served section. It will not show up unless you are registered.
